text: Jai Bhim!
And good morning, everyone.
It's a pleasure to be here.

And it's such a fitting
opening to really think

about how the realm
of the spiritual

can both enslave us, but
also bring us great opening.

And I think
certainly, as someone

who is a survivor
of the caste system,

this is really the meat
of my work and the things

that I explore in my
book, The Trauma of Caste.

And for folks who don't know
a lot about the caste system,

the caste system is
a system of exclusion

that's at the foundation
of many dharmic lineages.

And it's a system
analogous to race

where, because of
a social fiction,

priests who developed these
systems basically set up

a hierarchy where every
job had a different layer
of spiritual purity.

So priests were at the
top, rulers were next,

merchants followed,
then there was peasants.

And then there was
a group of people

who were seen to be so
spiritually defiling to all

of the other castes
because of crimes they

had done in a past life that
they were seen as untouchable.
And those are my people.

And I remember always
thinking about what

it meant to be
untouchable, because

for someone to touch you
was for them to experience
spiritual defilement.

But for us who were
born into those castes,

we were seen to be irredeemable
and without a place
towards God.

And that is a tremendous
thing to say about anybody,

let alone to be the foundation
of a system of exclusion.

And I think that is
really what really

made me hone in on how
traumatic the caste system was,

because certainly we are the
most underdeveloped communities

in the world, and over
1.9 billion people live
under a caste system.

And in the United States,
over 5.7 million South Asians,

you know, endure and
struggle with the exclusion
related to caste.

But I think that for
me, the piece that

was the most heartbreaking
was this condemning of being
someone without divinity.

And I think the course of
my own path of building--

turning pain into
power, and also

figuring out ways
that we might heal

as a South Asian community, and
all communities that struggle

under caste systems, was really
looking at that piece of where

we can understand
ourselves to be survivors

of religious abuse, but
also find opening when we

acknowledge that pain to find
the ways that we might return
humanity to each other.

And that is really one of the
profound messages in my book,

is that when you look
at systems of exclusion,

particularly those
like the caste system,

we have a tremendous
responsibility for us

as communities that are wanting
to engage around practices

of the ways that we
might be taking practices

like socially-engaged
Buddhism and being people who

are transforming our
institutions through our faith,

that we also have to acknowledge
how institutions of faith
have been weaponized to harm.

And I think that I
really had probably

grappled with all of the
socio-political understandings

of caste throughout my career
as an expert of caste and DEI
and caste equity.

I don't think I had
reckoned with my own pain

as being a survivor
of religious abuse.

And some of those things, when
you're born as an untouchable,

you don't feel like you belong
to any religious community.

And especially because of that
sense of spiritual defilement

and never feeling truly clean
or part of any community.

And that path towards
healing, that path

towards integration
to humanity, that

is the journey that most
caste-oppressed people have
to take.

And I think it really
begins with first saying,

yes, I am a survivor
of religious abuse,

and no one gets to determine
our path towards God.

And I think I've been
really lucky in terms

of the many different racial
justice, gender justice,

and workers' rights
movements that have really

begun to flank caste-oppressed
people like myself

around the country as we
speak our truth, both about

our pain, but also
the power that we

want to build as we
come out of the closet
everywhere around the world.

And the thing that I
find most profound is

the first step of our
freedom is we actually
lose the word untouchable.

Nobody gets to use that
word, it's seen as a slur.

But we call ourselves Dalit:
those that have been broken,

but are now resilient as we
move our path towards freedom.

And the thing that I think
that is so profound, especially

about the work that we're
doing in North America,

is that even though
caste-oppressed people are

some of the oldest oppressed
peoples in the world,

no one expected caste
to be brought here

to the United States because
there's no reason for it.

We don't-- dominant-caste people
are not in power in the United
States.

This is not the
historical lineage

of how we understand systems
of oppression here in the US.

We may understand the US as a
result of settler colonialism

and the result of the
enslavement of kidnapped

Africans, but we
do not understand

what has happened here
in the United States

as a result of the caste
system from South Asia.

So why are we seeing
caste operate here?

And in our work, I am
the Executive Director

of Equality Labs, we are a
national Dalit civil rights
organization.

Our research was some
of the first research

to find that South Asian
immigrants had unfortunately

brought caste to
every institution
that they are a part of.

And in our research, 1 in
4 caste-oppressed people

experienced physical and
verbal assault; 1 in 3,

educational
discrimination; and 2 out
of 3, workplace discrimination.

And usually when I say
those numbers to people,

people are like, oh,
you mean in India.

And I have to say, no,
here in the United States.

And when we look
at that, again, I

have to go back to
this idea of trauma

because I think
for many folks, we

are used to thinking
about systems of exclusion

through their political
realms, maybe even

their economic and
development realms,

but we are not used
to thinking about them

through the lens of
intergenerational harm
and trauma.

And that, I actually think, is
one of the most important ways

that we need to start engaging
with systems of exclusion,

because we can change the
laws to make discrimination
unlawful.

But if we don't change
the hearts and the minds

and the conditioning of
the nervous systems of both

the oppressed and
the privileged,

we will mindlessly
recreate these systems
whether we want to or not.

And I think that there is
a great deal of work that

has been done by Indigenous and
Black somatic and mindfulness

practitioners to really lift
up that integration of ideas

for all of us, because we are
in this really massive crisis

moment as global societies,
where we are seeing systems

of domination that we
thought had been put away,

or trends of right-wing
movements that we had thought,
"We've done that.

We've already dealt
with Nazis, we

don't have to deal
with that anymore."

And yet we're seeing the
resurgence of these movements

without any understanding
in a broad way as to what's
happening.

And I think this is really
what really inspired

me to write my book as well,
is that coming into 2019,

this was a profound
moment, I think,

for those of us who are
in South Asian communities

because we saw the opening
of a large genocidal project
in our homelands.

It's a result of years
of building rising
ethno-nationalism.

And there was a sense of
despair with almost everyone

that I knew that in some ways
the democracy that we knew

in South Asia that
was the birth of all

these modern
democratic republics,

whether it was Pakistan
or India or Bangladesh,

we had a sense that there
was a moment of possibility

for our communities to leave
behind centuries of violence
and discrimination.

And yet here we were
at the opening of 2019

into 2020 at this huge
genocidal project that

was launched in India
against hundreds of millions

of minorities, and people really
just didn't know what to do.

And it's a result of
endless cycles of violence.

And I think that in looking
at that, as someone who's

worked on this for many years
who was actually talking

to many of my elders and
mentors who were just

heartbroken, because
they had seen all

of their wins of their lives
being unmade before them,

I felt that we needed
another path, another way.

And as I started to engage with
other thinkers who were also

looking at the way that
trauma, looking at the way

that we could start to
look at the training

of our nervous systems around
these systems of exclusion,

you start to see that there is
a growing body of work that's

helping us try to make sense
of this very difficult moment.

And I really want to
lift up the thinkers

like Eduardo Duran and Maria
Braveheart who first really

pushed open this
door of thinking

about large systems of
exclusion through the lens
of intergenerational trauma.

And Eduardo Duran spoke a lot
about this idea of the soul

wound, a wound that exists
in someone that's not just

about their existing pain, but
it's the pain of their lineage

that comes from these
systems of violence.

So for Indigenous
people, it might

be that of settler
colonialism and genocide.

And Resmaa Menakem
took this idea

and then talked about it in
terms of the racial soul wound,

and talked about
how those of us who

have experienced the pain
of enslavement could feel--
or the pain of racialization--

would feel it as the
racial soul wound.

And I think these
ideas of looking

at that pain across
generations opens up

a different
understanding for how

we see this endless
cycle of violence

across these very painful
systems of domination.

Because then we're
not just looking

at what is happening to the
bodies and the nervous systems

of the oppressed, we are
also looking at the ways

that the bodies and the nervous
systems of the privileged

are also trained
in a particular way
under these nervous systems.

And as I examined that
in the context of caste,

it made a lot of sense,
because certainly

for Dalit people like
myself, the burden

of dealing with the caste
system is solely on ourselves.

We are responsible for both
breaking the silence about it,

as well as documenting the
crimes and the context of how

it just ravages our bodies and
minds and spirits every day.

But we also face
extreme gaslighting

and tremendous
amounts of violence

when we do come out
about this issue.

Even for myself, I have
had to be, live in--

I've had thousands of rape
and death threats for talking
about the issue of caste.

I've lived in safe houses
for breaking this issue out
into the American public.

And all because we're telling
the simple truth that caste

exists, there is
severe discrimination,

and we need a remedy
in American policy.

But to move through that
cycle and understand

what the grief is and the pain
is as Dalit people around it,

it's a tremendous
thing to also then put
the lens on the privileged.

And I've really
learned so deeply

from the work of Black
Buddhist thinkers

like Lama Rod Owens who
will be speaking after me.

But also Rhonda
Magee and Ruth King

who have taken the practice
of mindfulness to then

start to put a spotlight
on the conditioning

of the nervous systems
of the privileged.

And that's-- to do that is not
to decenter the experiences

of the oppressed, but it's
actually to also to remind

those who are in privileged
bodies that you are part
of this process, too.

It's not like race
happens to another body

and you're outside of it, or
caste happens to another body
and you're outside of it.

Oftentimes, bodies
of the privileged

really have no tolerance
for the conversation

that they have exempted
themselves from,

despite the fact that they're
gaining incredible amounts
of privilege.

And so to slow down enough to
be able to have people become

self-aware and think
deeply about their lineage

and their training around these
soul wounds, this is, I think,

one of the most fundamental
works that we need to do

as socially-engaged Buddhists,
as people who are people who
are trying to be--

to make moral choices
in difficult times.

We need to bring
our whole selves

to the process of social
change, especially when we

want to be in
institutions that we

lead with our hearts
and our moral compasses
in the right direction.

And I found that when we
are able to give grace

for those who are both suffering
from that of oppression,

but also those who have
been benefiting from it,

there is an opening where
we can start to begin
bridges of conversation.

I'm not saying that
we're always going

to agree because we
certainly don't always agree,

but right now, we are in
such a place of polarization

where caste-oppressed people
and caste-privileged people

are in such far divides
of this conversation,

we're not even able to
have a shared reality.

And this is true across
many systems of oppression
right now.

We are seeing such a divide that
we no longer have consensus.

And so I think some of these
tools that are coming out

of Black and Dalit
and Indigenous

somatic practitioners and
socially-engaged Buddhist

practitioners, there
are tools here,

I think, that are really
about us slowing down, knowing

that there's
disagreement-- and I

view disagreement in this
context as deep suffering

because of how much trauma has
separated us from each other.

That in many ways, if
we are able to begin

to build more
resilience in the bodies
of the privileged for smaller--

even a small amount of caste
stress or racial stress
or gender stress--

that ability for us to build
more resilience in those bodies

help us, then, begin
to slowly have more
conversations about consensus.
And do I think that's hard?
Yes, absolutely.

As someone who has been
working on caste equity,

I have seen how difficult
it is to cross divides

of discrimination
and bias, especially

with caste, which is one
of the oldest systems
of discrimination in the world.

And it's not only
one of the oldest,

it's really also
one of the systems

that there just is not
a lot of spotlight on.

And as there has
become a growing

amount of global
conversation on it,

dominant-caste people who've
been benefiting from the system
are not happy at all.

And the kinds of techniques
and the strategies

that they use to shut down
Dalit people is horrific.

For example, last
year, I was actually

supposed to give a talk about
Google about caste equity,

and people wrote
in and complained

and they said, "If
this speaker speaks,
I am afraid for my life."

And I always joke with
my colleague, Tanuja,

who had to deal with this
who was inside Google,

I said, "Well, I know that
people feel uncomfortable

with DEI, but I've
never met anybody
who has died from a DEI talk."

But I certainly know that there
are people who feel discomfort.

And so while we organized
inside of Google

around this issue
related to caste equity,

we saw tremendous, tremendous
worker power being built,

but also utter resistance
from management on this issue.

And this is, I think, one of
the most profound pieces that I

think we also have
to grapple with,

is that when we are
turning to things

like socially-engaged
Buddhism to find openings

in times of deep suffering,
there are times where we also

have to begin to
loosen our attachments

to the structures that
perpetuate violence
and discrimination.

And so I think for me,
my first truth has been,

I must first speak my
experience as being
a survivor of religious abuse.

My next piece has been, I need
to transform my conditions

to be able to make sure
that no one experiences

what I have experienced as
someone who is caste-oppressed.

And for me here in
the United States,

my focus is in transforming
American institutions

so that caste-oppressed workers
don't face discrimination

in their workplaces and
educational institutions.

And that experience that Google
launched an entire workers

movement across the
tech sector where

you have thousands
of tech workers

who are speaking about
the need for remedy

by adding caste as a
protected category.

And they are now
joined by workers

all around the country who are
asking remedy from governments,

from corporations,
and from universities,
wherever they might be.

And we are very lucky
to be at Harvard,

which was one of
the, the second,

Ivy League schools to add
caste as protected category.

And I'm speaking
now from California

where we are leading a
campaign to have California

be the first state in
the country to add caste
as a protected category.

And this is a
tremendous thing to see

some of the most
oppressed peoples

in the world come
out of the closet

and speak about what
is happening here
in the United States.

And it's been an honor to
be part of this process,

because again, I am a
civil rights activist,

I do a lot of writing, and I
am my own personal Buddhist

practitioner, but
I never expected

you know hundreds of
thousands of people

around the world to take
this spirit of freedom that

came from confronting their
own internal conditions

of suffering and then use it
to transform the institutions
in the material world.

But that's exactly what's
happening right now
with the Caste Equity Movement.

And if you ever catch
any one of those hearings

or you see any of
those news articles,

the stories of how people
are turning pain into power

is tremendous, because we
see, in terms of our side,

we have people who are Uber
drivers and people who cleaned

up COVID wards, people who
are caregivers, people who

are doctors and nurses and
lawyers, and, of course,

techies, all of whom
who have stories
of severe discrimination.

And yet, on the
other side, we have

people who are uncomfortable
with the prospect of sharing

space with caste-oppressed
people who simply want
to be free from discrimination.

But discomfort is not the
same as grave discrimination.

And I think this
small experience

of what caste-oppressed
people are doing

in the state of
California, I think,

is an example for
all of us in terms

of how we can see
socially-engaged Buddhism

transform the many institutions
that we might go into.

Is that for us to say that we
are willing to be unattached

to the things that
cause us suffering

means we must be
completely committed
to the freedom of all beings.

And in order to do
that, we must learn,

we must be willing to
confront structures

that are allowing
grave discrimination,

and to also look at
all of the dimensions

that systems of
oppression operate in,

whether it's internal,
interpersonal, or structural.

And so for me, I
think that in speaking

about the trauma of
caste, it isn't just

about the pain
and the wound that

connects the oppressed
and the privileged,

it's also about how
that wound becomes

a portal for greater
understanding and a greater

opening and reconnection
to humanity.

Because I don't think
Buddhism was ever

about simply going to
the top of a mountain

and thinking about the ways that
you might detach from humanity
and live in this rarefied air.

I think it was about how
we find the enlightenment

with each other, the ways
that we lift ourselves up

as a species, and transform
not only the institutions

that we're part of,
but our relationships

across the entire
spectrums of the Earth.

Whether it's with ourselves,
other species, and the planet,

this need for reconnection, this
is the heart of the practice.

And I think that if we
can center in healing,

our vehicles of rage
and our vehicles of love

will ultimately transform
us and the planet.
Thank you.
Jai Bhim.
